review:
To fully understand my review, must explain a few things. I come to owning the iPad Pro 9.7" via a long lineage of Macs, iPods, iPhones and iPads. I've owned five MacBooks since 2006, the iPhone, iPhone 3G, iPhone 4, iPhone 4S, iPhone 5, iPhone 6 and iPhone 6S. I've also owned the iPad Mini 2, iPad 4, iPad Air 2, and for a brief time, the iPad Pro 12.9".

The minority of upgrades along this ownership have been truly revolutionary. Moving to the Retina MacBook Pro from a regular 13" MacBook pro was a huge one. The iPhone 4 over the iPhone 3G was pretty huge.

After thinking about the iPad Pro 9.7", it's hard to say whether it's a revolutionary upgrade. I'm leaning toward "no," but I could be swayed over time. The reason I got rid of the 12.9" model was that it was way too big to fly with (I'm a private pilot who uses it for navigation/charts) and I was unable to procure an Apple Pencil due to low stock. Now that I have a true iPad Pro *and* the Apple Pencil, I'm more qualified to talk about what kind of upgrade this is.

Some things I like:

4 speakers: Apple has finally caught up with other manufacturers who give you stereo sound by default, even on cheap tablets. Heck, my old Nexus 7 2nd generation even had stereo speakers. So, when I upgraded from that to an iPad Mini 2, it was a downgrade speaker-wise. Now I feel like I'm back where I should be. The speakers on the Pro 9.7" are not *quite* as mind-blowing as the speakers on the 12.9", but they're still better than any other iPad that came before. For their size, they're truly fantastic.

Pencil: Wow, this is progress. It doesn't sample quite as fast as the Pro 12.9", but it's still very much as close to a pen-and-paper writing experience as you can get. The quality of the experience depends highly on the quality of app you're using, and I can say I really like Adobe Sketch and Procreate. For taking note and annotating PDFs  the primary reason for this purchase over keeping an iPad Air 2  I really like Notability. The pencil support in Notability is good, about 80% there, but makes annotating PDFs a real joy compared to the hassle of dealing with print. My handwriting is terrible, and Notability does a good job replicating it to a T. I write small, and much to my surprise, the Apple Notes app is much poorer at recording my small bad handwriting than is Notability. Interesting how a native app does worse than a 3rd party app on what is supposed to be a killer feature.

Battery life: Great!

Speed: Lightning fast for everything. I can't tell how much faster it really is than the iPad Air 2, but benchmarks seem to be putting it ahead favorably. Multitasking is very very fast.

Negatives:

Battery charge time: Still slow! Apple needs to up their charging game if they want to remain competitive. I'm used to my Apple products taking a significant charge in a short period of time, but it's just not the case with the iPad Pro.

Screen space: I know I intentionally got rid of the iPad Pro 12.9" in favor of this one, but I feel like I run out of palm space a lot when I'm writing with the Pencil. I'm a southpaw, so sometimes I'll just write on the right side of the screen and/or keep another app open on the left side where my palm can rest.

Multitasking: Apple really needs to find a way for any two apps to multitask. What about having two instances of Safari open side-by-side? Ability to instantly swap sides? All missing.

TouchID speed: Still a first-gen sensor (think iPhone 5S... old, right?), which is much much slower and less accurate compared to the sensor on my iPhone 6S.

Overall, I like the iPad for what it is. I think that for $820 after tax for the iPad, Pencil, and magnetic screen cover, I have a right to expect a bit more progress on certain items. iPads were already expensive enough at $500, but they need to do a little bit better of a job justifying the "Pro" part of the "iPad Pro."

My last iPad was the third generation and that was 4 years ago. Now it has gotten old and slow. So, two months ago I started to look at new devices. Surprise! My husband bought me the 12.9" iPad Pro. Very nice device but BIG!!!! So hubby took over the new IPad and I waited until the latest iPad Pro 9.7" was released.  The 9.7" Pro is a bit narrower than the old iPads but has the same sized screen. Unless you have really big hands and long fingers the 12.9" Pro is unwieldy to hold as a tablet and to type. Also, the 9.7" Pro is much lighter weight than the older models full sized iPads and the same weight as the iPad Air.  The graphics are exceptional as is the upgraded 12MP camera. It will not take the place of a DSLR camera for the camera buff but for me, who loves to take pictures of family, pets, and items to list on eBay, it is awesome. There is another feature that the camera does which is called a "live" shot. It is not a video but a mini snipit of about three seconds. This feature literally brings a picture to life. You hold your finger on the shot and it comes alive.  It is the difference between taking a picture of a child as they blow out that first candle on their cake and actually seeing the child blowing it out. Amazing!  As an long time iPad user I knew that I would need at least the 128GB for my apps, updates, pictures and music. Even though we subscribe to a 200GB iCloud storage plan it is amazing how quickly all that data takes up space. It would be a real shame to buy a device and skimp on something so basic. My first iPad did not have cellular and that was a big mistake for me, personally.  Public wi-if is not secure so I was limited to take a risk and use it or go without. It was a real bummer when we lost power!!!!!  Most cellular plans will let you hook up to 10 devices for $10 dollars each a month. This is a small price to pay to always be connected and to have your identity protected.  Will this take the place of a desktop or laptop? For me it does 99 percent of the time. It is perfect for social networking, skyping, uploading pictures, writing documents and printing them off of a wireless printer and, of course, on-line shopping. If I was still in grad school or running a business then I would probably need a laptop or desktop. As with all Apple products they are intuitive. The set up is a breeze and if you have an issue the Apple support team is just a phone call away. I am loving my new iPad 9.7 Pro and I know you will, too!

Thanks for reading my review and for pressing the "helpful" button if it was helpful to you. If you have questions and I can help please do not hesitate to write to me.

I just started using the iPad today, so I will update this review after I've spent more time using it. My first impression is very positive! It's a beautiful device. So sleek and thin. It's my first Apple device and I am in love with the interface. It's intuitive, colorful, great to use. The fingerprint reader is awesome and makes signing in and purchasing apps extremely convenient. The Apple Pencil is compatible with this version of the iPad, which is lots of fun. I like the multi-task feature a lot. I purchased this to use with the Apple Pencil as a drawing tablet, but after seeing the gorgeous screen I think this will become my device of choice for watching movies too.

When you get the device, make sure that the first thing you do is to install updates. If you don't have the most up-to-date version of iOS, you won't be able to download certain apps.

Also - Before you make your purchase, see what the prices are for different storage sizes. The silver 256 GB was cheaper than the 128 GB. Pretty incredible deal!

As I have had other similar sized iPads in the past, I was initially not sure if I wanted to purchase another iteration of the 9.7 iPad or not.  It turns out it was a spectacular decision.  The differences in the "pro" version of this tablet have set it apart head an shoulders over the others in the family.  First, is the screen - it just looks better.  The adaptive display is subtle and very, very clear.  I prefer to change the font to bold as it pops a bit more - but man is it easy to see.  It is easy on the hands too..  i know this sounds funny, but some screens you fingers get caught up on when you run them across the surface - this one does not seem that way.  Now lets talk storage 256 gigs.  I am not going to run out of room.  I can install whatever i feel like without having to stress out about it.  Next is the cellular service - I travel - and the ability to access my service wherever I go - without having to tether to my phone or rely on iffy wifi hotspots is very very nice.  But the BIGGEST and nicest feature of all on this tablet is the sound.  OMG  they put four little speakers (one on each corner) or this thing that will tear your head off.  When you hear a piano - it SOUNDS like a piano.  Now you won't be shaking the floor with it...  but make no mistake..  this is a geometric leap in sound reproduction over any tablet that i have heard yet.  If i had heard one of these tablets on a showroom floor - I would have bought it on the spot.  If you are a person who likes playing games and watching movies, this is THE go to table for portability and functionality.  Love it.

This review is for the 32 GB version, wi-fi and cellular version. Included in the box is just the tablet, wall plug and lightning cable. I have never considered myself a fan of Apple products, although I have always liked the old I-pod classics and still use one of those for my music collection to this day. I come from a mixed household though with both Apple and Android phones, using an I-phone for work and a S6 for my personal cell. I have also had Android tablets, although budget level ones. After finding a good deal on this I-pad pro, I decided to get one. One thing that Apple does well is the design of its products. The I-pad chassis is sleek, sturdy, stylish and well made. One complaint that I do have with the design is the lack of an external SD memory slot, although I do have that complaint with both Android and Apple phones as well. External memory can be added though with the I-pad using a lightning plug thumb device, although that may prevent charging depending on the brand, or a wireless hard drive which is cheaper than buying the more expensive I-pads that have more memory. The Apple OS, I don't think is as user friendly as the Android but most of the differences are pretty subtle as each revision of the OSs seem to mimic features of the competitors. I do like the cleaner look and more customizable nature of Androids screens though. Most of the apps are pretty similar although I like google maps better than the Apple version. The pro is lightning quick with apps and much faster than any of my previous cheap Android tablets. It so far has handled anything I have thrown at it with no issues at all, whether is its net surfing, playing videos, music, skyping or whatever. I decided to get the pro over the regular I-pads so that I can use different accessories such as the pen. I am currently using a generic brand Bluetooth keyboard which works just fine with the pro at a cheaper cost. If you don't use the cell portion of the device, one thing I noticed is that I would get a pop-up indicating no sim card often. I turned off the cell signal in the settings which helped but still get that pop-up from time to time. I am not sure how to completely make that go away. The tablet is lightweight and easy to carry around, although I don't dare use it without a protective case as I could see this easily cracking the screen if dropped. Because of that, I also got the Apple care which gives an additional year of warranty and covers replacement with accidental damage. For something as expensive as this, I think it is worth it. Display resolution is great and sharp. The display is easy to read with apps and with any print. Although I won't use the camera for picture taking, the camera is also very good for both pictures and video. I regularly use this for Skype and the video is sharp and clear. The speakers in this are better than any tablet or phone I have used so far. I won't say they will blow you away but they are clear and loud considering the size. I personally use an external Bluetooth speaker for most home use but the speakers are passable when on the road. Battery life is also good at around 10 hours or so. My one grip with Apple products is not about the quality but the price, I think the devices are a bit expensive as well as the accessories. I found a good price on this one but I would not get one for the normal prices that these usually are. Now that the new 10.5s that are out, maybe the prices will be more reasonable with these as these are pretty comparable to the 10.5 version in terms of specifications. After using this for a while and not being a long-time fan of Apple, I can see why people love these products as they are well made and nicely design. Although I do think they are pricey and have some OS features (or lack of) that I like better in the Android OS but overall this is a great tablet. 4 stars

I ordered this last Wednesday (5/24) with 2 day shipping and I didn't receive the iPad until yesterday (5/30), which wasn't a huge deal, but when I opened the amazon box I could see that the plastic seal around the iPad box had been previously tampered with or a new wrap was put on (not tight like the ones from apple). The plastic dust cover over the iPad itself looked very foggy or smudged and the iPad was mildly dusty, I don't see an option to submit a photo here but I will email it upon request. Even after being a little wary after opening the box once I plugged the "new" iPad in to the "new" charger it took an hour and 10 min to turn on. I then unplugged the iPad to apply a glass screen protector and when I plugged it back in the iPad would no longer charge. I thought maybe it was my outlet; it was not. I decided to plug the iPad into my iPhone charger to see if it would work and sure enough it did. This feedback is not meant to sound rude at all. I just don't like the fact that the iPad was described as new when I feel like it was refurbished or at least pre-owned. There is no reason for a brand new charger to stop working after about 2 hours of total charging. If I wanted to by a previously owned or refurbished iPad I would've bought one that was selling for less (but I wanted a new one). Hopefully this can be worked out, because I am not disappointed with the iPad in general, just the charger and description.

I got this as a birthday/graduation gift. A bit of background, I'm a college student (Geology Major), who was looking for a replacement for pencil and paper note taking and my aging, heavy Lenovo y50. The Lenovo y50 was originally designed as a semi-portable gaming laptop, weighing approximately 7-8 lbs, and 4 hours of battery life. It was designed to stay put on a desk with light travel. This is my 3rd and final year in university after transferring from a junior college. Taking notes with pencil and paper was my bread and butter since I was in elementary school.

Both of these things were hitting a brick wall. Pencil and paper note taking wasn't cutting it, as I was missing notes or information wasn't sticking. My Lenovo was really heavy after a long day at school and/or work and the wear and tear was starting to show on it. I was looking at a replacement; something light, powerful, good battery life stylus (5+ hours between charge with wifi, Bluetooth, and applications running) was a must, and good build quality. I first looked at the Surface Pro 3/4. A few friends had it and seemed like it ticked those boxes. However, after playing around with it, that for the price and usage, I realized that it was a laptop replacement. My girlfriend recommended her Samsung Tab A as well. While the battery was nice, the build quality left something to be desired. I also realized that I wanted a large enough tablet to have a comfy keyboard. The 3rd party Tab A keyboard was made tiny so that it would fit into a case for the tablet. I have tiny Donald Trump hands and I thought it.

Enter the IPad Pro 9.7.
It isn't a replacement for your laptop, I don't care what Tim Cook says. It sure as a hell can be used in tandem and  supplements a laptop though. I went for the smaller size, because the 13" inch one felt unwieldy for being an on-the-go item.

Build Quality: I can say that I'm not an Apple guy, but neither am I an Apple hater.  I knew an Apple machine by those smooth, machinned aluminum casings, comfy keyboards, superb touch pads, and that glowing Apple. I never got one though because for the price and spec sheet, they always seemed overpriced and underpowered. The same went for the iPhone; it looked aesthetically nice, but seemed like one paid more for the same. The iPad Pro is a beauty. This, along with my One Plus 3 phone, feel like some "2001: A Space Odessy" future tech. The screen is bright and color accurate; since buying the tablet, I have never turned off True Tone. The tablet is light, yet sturdy, comfy and unassuming. It's a confidently designed machine, never bragging about what it is, but it has gravitas. You know what else has gravitas? The battery. It will keep going for days. Apple says SOT is approximately 10+ hours, which I've gotten comfortably. I have to really push this thing to get from 100% to single digits by the end of the night. The speakers on this little guy are no slouch; it can get loud and clear, with no distortion. I'll admit, I was skeptical of having 2gb RAM and a dual-core 2.16GHz processor wouldn't be up to the task, but I'll handle it to Apple, they squeeze every last bit of processing power and memory cache they can.

Software: IOS is an odd thing. I do think Andriod is currently the better mobile operating system, but there is something to be said about IOS simplicity. My screen is never cluttered, as my apps are packed neatly away in folders or on the home bar. The settings are simultaneously simple and informative, all without hunting. Siri is a nice, fun addition, for nothing too difficult like directions, weather, or where to eat. When apps are designed well, they usually preform better on IOS than Andriod. For example, Google Drive is intuitive on IOS and feels very much like the desktop version, with easy access to other apps. IOS has become my one stop shop for paper to digital to editing said paper. While I wish IOS was more customizable, I don't usually mind it.

Personal Usage (Why it's not "Pro," more like "NCAA") : As I said earlier, I'm a college student. I take notes via Notability. I write essays via Google Docs/Microsoft Word. I watch videos on YouTube/Netflix/ Amazon Video. I do my shopping on Amazon/Etsy. I do have the Logitech Create keyboard case, because frankly the Smart Keyboard is silly. I use the Pencil for note taking mostly, but I have drawn with it; it's a nice stylus, but for what I use it for, it's pricey. Notability and my IPad are probably a huge reason for my grades getting a boost this semester. The recording function on the IPad and its usage in Notability is wonderful. The ability to take pictures with the camera and drop them into notes is a very nice function. The A9x processor and M9 coprocessor with 2gb RAM can handle multiple tabs open and I haven't noticed lag at all. I still close apps out of habit, but it's not necessary. I can read on the train, watch a dumb video on YouTube, and flip through my notes, all in one sitting.

If they really wanted this to be a pro machine, IOS needs to be gone, or at least heavily modified. IOS apps have nowhere near the full capability of a MacOS or WindowsOS. I would not want to edit video, work in AutoCAD, or make professional art on this machine. I really doubt the processing power is present in this machine. And for let's be real, I need my PC games. I can't play civilization 5 on this thing! This IPad feels like it wants to discover itself by doing casual art, but catching up on work, and then relaxing with Netflix at night.

TLDR: A svelte, powerful machine, that's not a laptop replacement, nor a oversized phablet. It's designed for light work, entertainment, and art. Ladies and Gentlemen, the IPad Collegiate.

The bad first: I can literally only complain about 2 things about this tablet. 1 Being how terrible the screen is for fingerprints. Like I work in a sanitized environment constantly washing my hands and my screen still gets absolutely disgusting. A fingerprint resistant screen protector can fix this. 2 Being that iOS arguably isn't the best OS for a PC Replacement. This is debatable to me because while the OS isn't aesthetically built to be a computer, it still does the same tasks. In fact to me, iOS is perfect in a tablet form factor. I use a tablet for media consumption and for school related things. iOS is straight to the point and less distracting with it's simpler format.

Design: 5/5 for design. This tablet feels amazing. I always appreciate great design language. Apple devices always feel so premium. Even though every year little changes between models, it just works. Better parts, thinner and lighter. That's all that ever really changes when it comes to design with Apple. The biggest addition has to be the speakers. Though found on the iPhone 7 and this tablets bigger brother, they were not on this guys predecessor, the Air 2. When you realize how thin this thing is yet how powerful it is, it truly blows your mind. It's thin but is so sturdy and tough. The aluminum is so hard to scratch or ding. The chamfered edges being the exception. I have a few nicks at the bottom of my tablet that I can't seem to place the blame on. But it's barely noticeable and if you use a case and screen protector you won't have this problem.
I hate to put cases on such beautiful devices. So I risk it. Holding all this power in such a thin profile is mind boggling. It feels so good in the hand. Has the perfect feel and weight. The metal build does mean a lack of wireless charging but that is a rarity on any tablets and isn't even a iPhone feature. The worst thing I can say is aluminum absorbs temperature easy. So if it is cold, it will be like holding a slab of ice. No tablet feels as premium as this one. I have used most of them. The Pixel C is the closest competitor in design to this tablet.
The bezels are perfect. Just enough for me. My hands just sit perfect without accidentally touching the screen, though the palm rejection is amazing. The speaker placement is perfect. I hardly ever block the sound. Though laying it on a surface will muffle it a bit. The Touch ID is nearly perfect. Not to fast and works every time. I just wish it was a capacitive like the iPhone 7. That would make it feel even more premium then it is.
The camera hump tends to be everyone's gripe. Camera humps never bother me. Most people put cases on their devices anyways. With as powerful as the camera is, the hump is well worth it.

Camera(s): 5/5 It's weird they put such a powerful camera lens on such a big device. It's awkward for most people to use a tablet for its camera. But the camera is so good, if I need to take a shot I'll use this over my phone if the tablet is conveniently near me. It adopts both cameras from the 6s. The back camera is 12MP and the front is 5MP. The front camera is important because Apple customers use FaceTime. It's nowhere as good as it could be but looks so much better then the 1.2MP found on the Air 2 and IPad Pro 12. Tablet manufacturers should worry more about the front camera anyways for better voice chat and selfies, sense those are easier to take and less awkward. You won't find a better camera on a tablet other then one on the Tab S3. But that's can be subject to opinion as well because I have always appreciated Apples less saturated shots.
The camera has HDR, shoots 4K, it shoots slow motion and burst shots.

Battery: 4/5. The battery lasts long. I use this thing at least four hours a day and am never usually less then 60% when I go to charge it. That's with the volume up and the screen at 75% brightness. Games are the only thing you can do on this device that will drain it significantly. If your just typing or reading, setting the screen on a lower brightness will make this thing last forever. Longer then any other mobile device. It's one of the reasons I prefer my iPad over a laptop. The standby time is  ridiculously long. In just a few hours it will only lose a couple percent. It can go days with out being charged if you only pick it up here and there for basic tasks.
The reason it isn't 5/5 is only because in a world of quick charging, this thing takes longer to charge. Not terribly long at all. However the 12 inch pro has a quick charger sold separately that significantly improves charge times. Since this came out after the 12 inch model, I have to dock it a point for not including the tech in this one.

Media: 5/5 Your not going to get a better experience on arguably any mobile device, especially tablets. Yes the Tab S3 has HDR, which is amazing. However I really do prefer retinas over amoled for many reasons. Amoled screens can get brighter and are more saturated yes. But the iPads Quad HD Retina is so easy on the eyes. Especially having the true tone display and night shift mode. As someone who reads A LOT, I can finally read books on a tablet with out eye strain or feeling like I am ruining my eyes over time. The true tone display works wonders!
The screen is gorgeous. After years of seeing Apple devices with less pixel density screens then all the competition, it's finally nice to see them actually make a display that I really appreciate. To top off the media experience is the one feature that sets it above all the rest of the tablets when it comes to appreciating content; four stereo speakers. I always appreciate stereo speakers. All devices should have them. This tablet has four and they sound AMAZING. Their even better then Bluetooth speakers I've owned. It really is a special experience to watch movies on, play games on or listen to music on. It gets really loud and the sound has incredible depth and base. When you look at how slim it is, you wonder "how does this thing make this much sound".
Games fly on this thing. The A9X is a very powerful SoC. Probably the most powerful chip behind the Snapdragon 835, 821 and the Apple A10. The 2 gigs of RAM is again, not a problem here. You wouldn't be able to tell at all based on how well games play on this thing.

Everyday Use: 5/5 This is the best tablet to me for everyday use. With its long lasting battery, beautiful screen and speedy performance you would be hard pressed to find a device more capable. Though I prefer Android most of the time, iOS shines on a tablet. I use my tablet for media consumption and school work. With its simple design and power, it breezes through everyday tasks in a simple fashion.

Power User: 4/5 For a power user this is still my favorite tablet. Sure the 12.9 incher has a bigger screen and double the ram which means better multitasking. However the 9.7 is much more portable and comfortable to use. In fact the only time I seen a noticeable difference in performance was when I was video editing. Most people aren't getting this device for video editing however and for the majority, this is the tablet for you.
With the Apple Pencil and keyboard case, you take things up a notch. Both are great products and make this the best main stream tablet for students and graphic designers.
The reason it isn't 5/5 is because of Windows 2 in 1 devices such as the Surface. These are still much better at performance, have a better keyboard and typing experience, and the styluses have more features. Their Windows 10 OS is much better suited for a power user. The iPad is a nice balance between power and simplicity however.

Comparison to the iPad Pro 12.9 inch: Yes the iPad Pro 12.9 has more RAM, a bigger screen and can charge faster if you buy the fast charger sold separately. The speakers are also slightly louder on the bigger model.
However those differences are argued above, and I still would go for the 9.7 inch model if I was you.
The true tone display being my biggest reason. It definitely makes a difference on eye strain and presents content better. It also has P3 color gamut, which is the same as the iMac 5K. Colors are better on the smaller one.
This model has a way better camera, is available in gold and is MUCH more comfortable to use. Also the 12.9 has way bigger black bars when viewing movies and television shows.
This model is so much lighter, and easier to hold making it a better on the go option. At the price and size of the 12.9 inch, you would be better off buying a MacBook Air.

Conclusion: I am in love with this device. I originally wanted the 12.9 inch Pro because my brother had it on our contract. Previously I had a Mini 2. THANK GOD they were out of the 12.9 inch models and I went with this one. The 12.9 is really ungainly.
This thing is beautiful, powerful, practical and simple. Especially with unlimited data from Verizon, it truly is the best mobile experience. Also unlike a Android slab, I can use this one for years to come with out it worrying about slowing down and breaking due to terrible design. I easily recommend this. It is probably my favorite thing that I own. I use it everyday a lot. I watch movies and YouTube on it, type on it and read books on it everyday. I don't even want to use my phone when this thing is around. This device was crafter by the Gods themselves.

Update: I have since acquired the 12.9 as well. I still really love my 9.7 more. It's screen is much prettier, it is comfortable in all situations and it feels and looks a lot better. You can't go wrong with either tablet. If you plan on multi-tasking a lot, keeping the tablet at home or only using it for games and movies then go for the 12.9. It's much better suited for these tasks. If you plan on reading a lot, carrying it to go and using it for everyday tasks, I would go for the 9.7
This update is simply meant to show I have experience with both, and didn't favor the 9.7 more because I was being biased.

I bought this and the Apple Pen with the hope of using one device to replace my 128GB iPad Air II and my Samsung Galaxy Tab A with S Pen. Not gonna' happen unfortunately.

I really like the iPad Air II. It will even answer my iPhone if they're both on the LAN. It won't let me add removable memory was complaint #1 and the Air II has rather crude stylus support was complaint #2.

The Galaxy Tab A I love. Pen support is great. The quick note feature where you scribble on the screen, even when it's locked, and it saves it, is pure genius. The stylus that hides in the case is too small to be comfortable for extended usage but I bought the $39 Wacom stylus that's pencil size and it's great. That's $39 Apple, not $99. And neither stylus needs to be charged. I can add micro SD memory. I can scribble a search argument into Yahoo, it converts it to text and does the search. It's accuracy doing this is better than my poor typing. I can hover over a foreign word and it will translate it. The biggest downside is it doesn't let me answer my iPhone.

Pen support for the iPad Pro is after the fact software dependent while it's a base function for the Tab A. Maybe someday Apple will catch up.

This isn't going to be a technical review. I like Apple products and it's kind of that simple. I have a Samsung Galaxy which I liked it it's giving up it's little ghost and I needed to replace it and dealing with two different operating systems was a little annoying plus it wanted my devices to be able to talk to each other. If you love Apple stuff you are going to love this.  If you hate Apple, you will hate it, but if you are on the fence I strongly suggest you try it out, and you will love it.  There is no comparison between an Android tablet and an Apple.  Even the top of the line Android tablet is not nearly as responsive or reliable as an Apple iPad.  I tried to hate Apple, I really did, and I went with Android, but after trying an iPhone and a tablet compared to my Android I realized that I was only punishing myself.  Who cares if Apple gets to approve all apps on the app store, they actually do that to ensure that the apps don't crash, leak memory or have viruses in them.  That's fine with me.  There really isn't anything that I could do on my Android that I can't do on my iPad.  That said, I don't jailbreak my iPad, and I pay for the apps that I use.  If you are looking for a way around that then the Android is significantly easier.  But, I love the interface on the iPad.  When I touch the screen and move something, it instantly follows me, with absolutely no perceivable delay.  I was amazed at how I had convinced myself that my Android did that, and just how tolerant I was of the poor user interface performance.  But, now that I have this pro, I won't look back.

As for the size, it is perfect for me.  I went to the store, and the full sized pro is just too big.  It is like a full sized laptop screen.  This is smaller, it is what I consider a tablet.  It has all the performance of the full sized, running desktop quality apps and games with absolutely no issue.  I opted for the 32GB model, because I don't load up too much on it, but now that I can see what it does I am wishing I went with more memory, especially now that they have 256GB available.

Even if you are an Apple hater, I strongly suggest you try one of these out.  They are quite more expensive than a normal Android tablet, but try it out and you will quickly see why.  The feel is solid and rugged, the case is a work of art, perfection.  The user interface experience is second to none.  I dare any Apple hater to use this, and still try to say that they hate apple with a straight face.

PROS: Well built, super fast, ideal sized, light weight, and batter lasts for days for me.

CONS:  Price is high, and I cannot upgrade the storage size.  But that is it.

Pretty much as we expected.  It has a terrific battery...much preferable to my Kindle Fire.  The photos really jump out at you, and since we can use our phone as a hotspot, there was no need to get a 4G and purchase another phone contract.  Another positive, as with all Apple products, is our phones are completely compatible being iPhones, and we can sync calendars, messages, music, documents and other items.  It is just slightly larger than the Kindle Fire I had been using to read the paper, and I welcome the increased screen size without needing to go to a 12 inch iPad, which would have been much harder to drag around.  We purchased a nice leather case (ProCase) with a document pocket, allowing it to stand up conveniently when reading on a table or desk.  There are also four speakers which generate good sound, that allows us to use it as a player without hooking it up to other equipment.  While we have compared the iPad Pro 9.7 to our Kindles, there is no getting around the cost difference.  The Kindles are way cheaper, so remember that.  All in all we are very pleased with our purchase and expect to use it for a long time.

With "True Tone", the display "adjusts" itself to "blend" with the environment to give you a more natural experience. It all sounds too fancy until you actually use it. In our office we have "bright white" lights, and if you're looking at a page, it seems all good, not too yellow, not too blue. This was an upgrade from my iPad4 from 2012. A couple things immediately noticed when I unpacked it was how light it was, and having a smaller border around the screen. The iPad Pro is deceptively light, as if it should be a heavier device based on my experience with my previous iPad. It's also thinner on the sides of the screen, making for a narrower model in contrast to the iPadv4. Having said that, the actual video screen itself is identical in size to the previous generation iPads. I intend on rarely using my new iPad to take pictures, but the camera is leagues better than the version 4 camera, both front and back. I also like the split screen option on the iPad Pro, since I can put my Cisco Jabber IM client off to one side of the screen and continue to web browse. I also purchased the Apple Pencil with the new iPad and downloaded the "Goodnotes" application from the app store. The app made a great first impression, with handwriting resolution that rivals a fine tip pen or pencil in real life. I like that it's Bluetooth versus capacitive, since I can rest the rest my hand on the screen and write normally, a feature not possible with capacitive writing devices. Being Bluetooth, the battery life on the Apple Pencil isn't great, but it recharges from the iPad Pro lightning port in like 5 or 6 minutes, which is pretty impressive.

Video Storage and Playback:
In 2012 I would've been against storing my movie collection with iTunes cloud, but having lost a few hard drives at home since then I kinda like the idea of Apple being responsible for my data, since they are more data storage resilient than I can ever afford to be at home. Even so I purchased the 256GB model so I can store a healthy volume of movies and music for when I travel, without being starved on storage space for the other applications. My iPad 4 was a 16GB storage and nearly half of the storage space was unusable even after a factory reset of the device with nothing on it; a mistake I won't repeat with future tablets or phones.

Battery life:
In watching a 2 hour movie on battery power, the percentage went down about 15%, which isn't bad.

Application switching and overall performance:
Noticeably faster than my iPad4. I still close unneeded programs when I am no longer using them, a habit I picked up from my other Apple device usage, but I don't notice a performance hit when 20+ applications are open at the same time on the iPad Pro, in contrast to the iPad4 version.

All in all it was a good choice and I think it future proofs my device when iOS 11, 12, and beyond come out. My iPad4 is noticeably slower since upgrading to iOS 10, so I anticipate it reaching its end of life in the next year or 2 worth of updates.

I love Ipads for what they are but Apple marketing continues to try to make them out to be more than they really are. This is a great iPad but hardly "Pro" (whatever that means in Apple ad-speak) and I think for the majority of users functionally no improvement over a recent iPad Air.

A such I would find this hard to recommend for most people over the current iPad Air and the next Air, supposedly coming in March, will reportedly have the AX 9 CPU as in the current 9.7 pro or perhaps the AX 10 (that will probably be the pro model). Finally getting more than 16gb RAM is liberating, particularly since Netflix will supposedly be allowing some off line viewing. In truth iPad apps have to be able to run on the large installed base of slower CPUs so I have read technical reviews indicating that Apple is in a bind touting the benefits of faster iPad CPUs. App developers can not afford to abandon platforms as Apple continues to do (e.g ports on the new MacBook Pro, no headphone jack on the iPhone 7).

Compared to my early model Ipad, which was circling the digital drain, the performance boost is remarkable for web browsing, but so is that of the current Ipad air. The faster processor allows access to splt screen, useful for the limited cutting and pasting possible in iOS. If you tether/clone your Ipad to your desktop/laptop again I am not sure the AX9 CPU will be a huge improvement over the CPU in the current iPad air. Although I use the front facing camera for Skype I almost never use the rear camera unless I need a snapshot and the iPad is in my hands at the time but the images seem in the ballpark for the generic digital Instamatic quality of cell phones and tablets.

As Apple does not allow a mouse/cursor (yet) in iOS I have never been able to use an iPad with any keyboard or stylus as a laptop replacement when traveling or for daily use, others may disagree, particularly for complex text or interacting with complex web pages some of which that I have to use do not even trigger the onscreen keyboard for text entry. Although I can see how the larger iPad pro could be useful for graphics pursuits it too is not a laptop replacement (and is too big for how I use an iPad). Honestly, I would invest in a Surface Pro (horrors) rather than the larger iPad pro but that opinion is just based on having used both of them.

So why did I buy this instead of the iPad Air? I had a few Amazon gift cards lying around and decided to splurge because, as noted, my old iPad was giving signs it planned to die soon and I did not want to wait until March for the new iPad Air--which I would do if I did not immediately need an iPad replacement.

Before starting my review, I must tell that I am a huge Apple Fan and I'm used to stuff like these. I come to owning the iPad Pro 9.7" via a long line of  Apple products like iMacs, MacBooks, iPhones and iPads. I've owned a couple of MacBooks (Recently reviewed the MacBook Pro 2016 with touch-bar ), the iPhone 4S, iPhone 5, iPhone SE, iPhone 6, iPhone 6S and iPhone 7 plus and now the iPad Pro 9.7"

The minority of upgrades along this ownership have been big changes with some flaws and some positives. Moving to the Retina MacBook Pro from a regular 13" MacBook pro was a huge one. The iPhone 6 from the 4s and 5 was a huge change in my life

After thinking about the iPad Pro 9.7", it's hard to say whether it's a revolutionary upgrade. I'm leaning toward "no," but I could change over time definitely it's useful having one though. The reason I got rid of the 12.9" model was that it was way too big to carry and work with, I haven't seen anything like that before and I was unable to buy the Apple Pencil at that time because I thought it was over-priced and not useful. Now that I have a true iPad Pro *and* the Apple Pencil thanks to the Black Friday sale, I'm more then happy to leave a review on this product.

Some things I like:

The sound quality: As I'm a music lover I'll talk about the sound first. Apple has finally caught up with other brands who give you stereo sound by default even on lower end tablets. The speakers on the Pro 9.7" are not as mind-blowing as the speakers on the 12.9", but they're still better than any other iPad that came before.

Pencil: Let's talk about something NEW Wow, this is so good. AGAIN it isn't as good as on the iPad Pro 12.9", but it's still very much as close to a realistic writing experience. The quality of the experience depends highly on the quality of app you're using, and I can say I really like Adobe Sketch and the pencil works wonders on that app. and for taking notes in class this pencil does the job. but I must say I had a bad experience with the Apple Notes app like a few other users here, and I agree with others that it's Interesting how a native app does worse than a 3rd party app on what is supposed to be a killer feature.

Battery life: No Words better then anything else !

Speed: Lightning fast for everything. I can't tell how much faster it really is than the iPad Pro 12.9" in terms of using it while standing or carrying it around, technically the benchmarks put some other branded tablets ahead.

The things I didn't like:

Battery charge time: Still slow! Apple needs to up their charging game if they want to remain competitive. I'm used to my Apple products taking a significant charge in a short period of time, but it's just not the case with the iPad Pro.

Multitasking: Apple really needs to find a way for any two apps to multitask. What about having two instances of Safari open side-by-side? Ability to instantly swap sides? All missing, It should be something like multitasking on the MacBook Pro 2016

TouchID speed: Still a first-gen sensor (think iPhone 5S... old, right?), which is much much slower and less accurate compared to the sensor on my iPhone 6S.

Overall, I like the iPad for what it is. I think around $800 after tax (when I bought). I have a right to expect a bit more progress on certain items. iPads were already expensive enough at $500, but they need to do a little bit better of a job justifying the "Pro" part of the "iPad Pro.". Especially when we can get a maxed out laptop for $800 ( Not Apple )

I was hesitant to invest in such a pricey tablet, but the iPad Pro is the best tablet on the market. I've had a Samsung Galaxy Tab A in the past and it was nice, but it in no way compares to the Pro. My favorite part of the Pro and main reason for buying it was to learn how to do brush calligraphy. The iPad and the Apple Pencil do not disappoint. I would highly recommend this tablet over any others on the market if you are a designer, creator or artist. This paired with the Apple Pencil is by far the best product for digital hand-drawn or calligraphic designs.

For those of you looking for a solid tablet to use as a companion to your laptop or desktop computer, again the iPad Pro is the way to go. It doesn't replace a computer in many regards, but it definitely allows for a lot of the wear and tear to be taken off of one. Besides doing calligraphy and other design related things on my Pro, I enjoy reading, watching tv and using it to write papers and complete other school projects. If you're a designer and need the full Adobe Creative Suite, I wouldn't recommend giving up your laptop for the Pro. But if you want a solid tablet that can take some of the stress off of your everyday computer, look no further.

Let me start this review by saying that I've owned a lot of tech and a lot of Apple products. iPad-wise, I've owned the iPad 3rd generation, iPad mini 2, and iPad Air 2. For this review, I'll probably do most of my comparisons to the iPad Air 2.
This iPad is honestly perfect. The four speakers are incredibly loud and clear. Apple fixed the annoying vibrate issue that plagued the iPad Air 2 that was caused by the speakers. While this iPad is the same dimensions as the former, it feels sturdier. The screen is absolutely gorgeous. I didn't think it could have much improvement from the last one, but it really is. Apple included a new feature called True Tone display, which uses four sensors to make the screen match the color temperature of the room. The cameras are the same as my iPhone 6S, and you can tell. My mom says I look so much clearer when I FaceTime with my iPad now. Speaking of the screen, I had a horrible problem with my iPad Air 2. Without a case, there were some moments if I held it with one hand that the distortion spots on the screen would appear from the pressure. The vibrate and screen issue I thought were from it being so thin, but Apple fixed both of those issues with the iPad Pro 9.7".
This iPad is also incredibly fast. Again, I didn't think there would be THAT much improvement from the previous generation, but I was wrong. It flies at everything I throw at it. My MacBook is a 2012 model that is showing its age. It is painful to use. Because my new iPad Pro has 128GB, I'm probably going to use THIS as my primary computing device.
The iPad Air 2 isn't a bad device, but you can definitely tell that THIS one is superior. It feels better in hand. The screen looks amazing. The speakers are loud and immersive. The battery life is better.
If you're a tech lover, buy this iPad. You will be much happier with your investment. I typed this review with a Logitech keys-to-go keyboard on my iPad Pro 9.7".

I bought an iPad Pro for school to use as an engineering student and it has been by far one of the most sound investments that I have ever made for school. The note taking apps that integrate the Apple Pencil into them are fantastic (The top two that I found were Goodnotes and Notability but I prefer Notability) and the keyboard that Apple sells as a 2 in 1 smart cover is pretty useful as well but a tad bit expensive for what it actually is. I have a lot of classmates that drool over me being able to have all my notes in one place and not have to carry around a different notebook for each class and how well it has helped with me being organized. But this is something that could be attained with any tablet for that matter. The reason why I chose to buy an iPad Pro over the other available tablets is because it syncs well with my Mac and my iPhone phenomenally as well as being reliable. If you are a fan of Apple products then you would be a fan of the iPad Pro, for whatever use to chose to put it to. But for me personally, this is a complete life saver when it comes to school. All my notes are in one place, they're backed up and synced to my iPhone, Mac, and iPad, I don't have to take my computer to class anymore or even to campus for that matter, and it's a lot more light weight than carrying around a million notebooks! All in all this is another Apple product that can be enjoyed by people who like what Apple offers it customers and this iPad offers a lot more than just your traditional iPad.

As much as I hate to admit it, this is the best tablet I have ever used, period. I do not like the idea of a monopoly on technologies, and so I do support and love products like the Surface Pro. The bottom line is that the iPad Pro is faster than it has any right to be, responsive beyond belief, and the battery lasts forever! While it may be running iOS, there are still plenty of apps to make up for the lack of a computer-style operating system. It is slightly easier to do things like word processing and video editing on something like the Microsoft Surface Pro, simply because you are not inhibited by the mobile operating system. Regardless, I would still give the iPad Pro the edge simply because it is so consistent in being responsive, lightning-fast, and doing exactly what you want it to. The Apple Pencil really should come with the iPad Pro because it is possibly the most impressive aspect of the whole Pro package. I have never used a more responsive stylus, with virtually zero lag, that actually captures exactly what I am writing or drawing. Apple may be last to join the bandwagon but they have once again, as usual, been the first to perfect the technology.

Just to preface this review, I owned the 9.7 iPad Pro before I got the big guy:  the 12.9.  Like many, I was convinced by the countless online reviews all basically saying, "Buy the 9.7.  The 12.9 is nice and big, but the 9.7 is a far more polished product:  Truetone display, better cameras, more portable, etc. etc.  Wait until a few more models come out and the tech has caught up to buy this monster.''

So I bought the 9.7, and it was awesome.  I loved it, and fully intended to keep it and continue using it.  Then, after 2 months, it was stolen.  I got an insurance check that covered the loss and thought, why not try out the 12.9?  Basically free at this point.  If I didn't like it I could just return it and get the 9.7 again, nbd.

So I got the 12.9 128gb with WIFI and LTE.  And it was even better--so much better in fact, that you couldn't pay me to go back to the 9.7.  Ladies and gentlemen, this thing is a bonafide game changer.  The smaller version hardly compares. Shop at the right place and you can get this for virtually the same price too.  Think of it this way:  you're shopping for a TV, and the salesman comes up to you and says, "We've got a 47' flat screen plasma for $630, but If you want, I'll sell you this 82' Plasma for just 40$ more."  It's a very easy choice to make.  Go big, or go home.  Take advantage of the fact that the bigger format has not yet taken off, and you can find it discounted down to the price of the standard size iPad Pro because this is a trend that will not last.

To anyone that says the 12.9 is bulky/not portable, that is simply untrue.  It's as thin as an iPhone and barely weighs more than a stack of printer paper of the same thickness.  Whoever says, "you might as well just be carrying a laptop everywhere," that is a woeful exaggeration.

The Apple Pencil, with either model, is a must buy accessory.  This addition is what sets the iPad Pro apart from any other tablet on the market.  It has a more natural, tactile feel than any stylus on the market (looking at you Surface and Galaxy Note), but it was made for the bigger version.  With the bigger version, the Apple Pencil is a legitimate tool, and a great one at that.  With the smaller version, the functionality of the pencil feels more like a toy--very cool, but more limited just by nature of the smaller work space, like an elementary school desk V. full size executive wrap-around.

Now, to those who say, "The camera's not as good on the bigger model, and the iSight camera's definitely not as good."  Look, just use your smart phone.  I know you have one.  I moonlight as a photographer, so take it from me, it is worth taking photos or video On some other device and having this massive, beautiful screen to edit them.  Plus, you don't want to be 'that guy' walking around holding a tablet in the air trying to get your master shots; no one will take you seriously.  Spielburg's not shooting his next block buster on any tablet, no matter how good the camera, and if you're an artist, you want the bigger view finder; the extra 4mp makes no difference.

As for the rest, the sound is not only louder, it's also better.  Size-wise, the bigger model actually feels better in terms of ergonomics--fits perfectly and securely across your lap in absence of a table or working surface and eliminates need to balance on a knee, squeeze your legs together, or even hold in the air, as was my experience on the smaller model, which makes the argument that "it's just too big to be comfortable holding for long periods of time," a moot point.

Battery life is better.  Bigger screen makes anything related to reading, watching, gaming, editing, typing, etc, better on the 12.9.  With the smaller model, the on screen keyboard is an awkward size, too big to use your thumbs like a smart phone/too small and cramped to type as with a traditional keyboard, and even the blue tooth keyboards (I've used apple and Logitech) feel small, cramped, and inefficient (unless you have very small hands I suppose).  This was one of the biggest limitations I had with the 9.7.  In contrast, with the larger one, the onscreen keyboard is big enough to get meaningful work done if you need to, past the capacity of quick text messages, and if you opt for a keyboard, the ones built for the 12.9 are basically the same scale as your typical laptop, offering a very easy transition.  My opinion:  get the Pencil for sure, but give the onscreeen one a chance before spending that extra 100$ on a keyboard case, which effectively doubles the size of this sleek machine.  I bought one at the same time I got the iPad, thinking I'd use it.  I don't.  Like, at all, and I type all the time.  But the onscreen keyboard is good enough that having another keyboard is simply redundant.  I typed this entire review with no help from a Bluetooth keyboard.  My guess, Apple developed the smart keyboards because they knew people would ask, and pay the extra money for them, not because they thought people would need them.

So-in summary, there's no arguing, both sizes are great products, but  you're not getting full "Pro" capabilities in the device unless you get the 12.9.

Do yourself a favor. Get the 12.9, NOT the 9.7.

I had an early iPhone, an incredible device which started a revolution.  But Android seems to have passed them by in terms of just about everything (except price).

I purchased this iPad out of necessity.  Certain specialized applications needed for my industry are only available for the latest iOS devices, and I also needed a way to validate websites I design freelance, which have received a lot of tech support calls that ended up being caused by iOS-9 doing some stupid things in the background (confirmed by this purchase and testing with it).

For review of the iPad PRO verses other iOS devices, about all I can say is I like having all the memory (since I can't add a uSD like any Andriod device) and one of my apps requires the iPencil, which is only for iPad PRO right now.

Review against Android devices, like the Samsung tablets, it's no contest.  Except that the Androids don't run the very specialized apps I need, I prefer them in every way, especially being able to add/upgrade memory, and pay about 1/2 the price for the same power and functionality.  "Retina" display is objectively no better than the latest Androids.  (Did you know that the iPhone's display is the same exact specs as the Galaxy S4, and made by Samsung?).  Siri doesn't seem to work as well as OK-Google for my use (I didn't have to train it).  For that matter, the new Cortana in Windows-10 (Anniversary update) is even better than OK-Google, putting Siri in a solid 3rd-place (then there is Amazon's Alexix, which I haven't tried).  Then the native spell-check.  At least Android gives me the option of going back to my original spelling (a dotted line under corrected text).  Not so iOS, if you don't purposefully select your original text, it gets auto-co-wrecked for you, and you have to proofread/hunt/replace.

Review of the iPad PRO against itself, it probably does it's best, because of the great speakers and iPencil support (separate review of the over-priced iPencil).  Biggest problem is that iOS9.3.x acts like a pig once it connects to the internet, constantly and rapidly crawling (like a search-engine) sites in your favorites and history for content updates (even when browser is not running) as well as looking for "iOS Optimized" websites by calling specific filenames that don't exist otherwise (i.e. "apple-touch-icon.png" and several variants) putting load on your dataplan and generating tons of 404's with website servers, which is interpreted by a lot of security software as aggressive probing, and can lead to host or IP denial (as my website clients started to complain when they got their first iOS 9.3 updates).  iOS 10 update was just released last week.  I'm holding off until I hear the first reports from others, so I can compare with my server logs what new probes it will be up to.

I realize this review isn't going to influence a YES or NO purchase decision.  This is my experience with the iPadPRO so far.  Price for what you get is the biggest hit.  If it was price-comparable to a Samsung tab with comparable power and features, it would still be one-star behind.  (It seems that almost all of my "not helpful" review ratings involve polarizing brand-name product comparisons.  Hmmmm.)

I purchased the iPad Pro 9.7 display in rose gold about 2 weeks ago directly from the Apple store online. This device is ideal for anyone wanting a smaller, lighter substitute for his or her laptop.

Display:
Discusses features related to the screen and display quality
 iPad Pro has a 9.7 retina screen display with 2048x1536 resolution giving the user exceptional detail.
 Colors are vivid and true to real life.
 The screen size is perfect for most users. It is small enough to be able to reach all spots on the screen, but big enough to utilize the dual screen feature, which allows you to open and use multiple apps at once.

Sound:
Discusses features related to speaker and sound quality
 iPad Pro has speakers in each corner of  the device, and, based on the orientation the user is holding the iPad, the topmost speakers are used to give the best sound quality possible.

Processor & Operating System:
Discusses features related to the processor and operating system
 This device contains the A9X chip with M9 coprocessor giving it power similar to a laptop, and giving it long battery life.
 The iPad Pro is compatible with Apples newest operating system, iOS 10, which includes cool features like live photo, 3D touch, and ability to delete some of the built-in apps that you may not use.

Ease of Use:
Discusses the user-friendliness and how easy the device is to use.
 As most Apple products, the iPad Pro is extremely user friendly and easy to use. The touch screen feels natural, and with just a swipe you can open the camera, or switch between apps.
 Even if you are not someone who is tech-savvy, the iPad Pro is easy to set up. Upon turning on your iPad for the first time, there are step-by-step instructions on how to set up your new device. There is also an option to have an Apple representative assist you with setup if you wish.

Durability:
Discusses the durability of the device.
 The aluminum backing of the iPad Pro is an improvement from earlier models, making it more durable and more scratch resistant.
 Although there may be cause for concern in regards to scratches on the glass portion of the screen, with the use of a smart cover, after two weeks in and out of a college students backpack no scratches have been seen.
 Caution should be used if children will use the device frequently. Apple offers many protective products to keep your iPad Pro is beautiful condition.

Function:
Discusses the overall function and purpose of the iPad Pro
 iPad Pro is a great device to substitute a laptop. Although all programs must be available on the app store in order to run on the iPad Pro, the programs available will run smoothly and quickly.
 iPad Pro is great for eBooks, photo apps, drawing apps, and word processing apps.

Other Cool Features:
Notes other features unique to iPad Pro
 With the iPad Pro, you are able to purchase an attachable keyboard making typing even easier.
 This device enables users to utilize Apple Pay, allowing you to link your credit and or debit cards to your iPad, and makes purchasing online easy.
 Since this is a more expensive device, security is important. The iPad Pro offers a finger print password option, which allows you to add multiple fingerprints to the device to keep your information secure.

The iPad Pro overall is a great device and will meet most of your technology needs. It is user friendly and makes traveling back and forth from campus and/or work easier and more enjoyable.

Just merely hours before I boarded my evening flight out of Seattle, with my final summer paycheck in hand, I purchased an Apple iPad Pro. When I walked into the Apple store that day I was looking for a product that would enhance my educational experience at Baylor. After taking notes on paper all throughout high-school, I figured that it was time to make a change. Having never owned a tablet, I probably fell for every sales pitch in the book that day because I not only walked out of the store with an iPad Pro but also an Apple Pencil and a Smart Keyboard. Although this came out to be a hefty purchase ringing out at $1299, I felt as if I had to stay loyal to the Apple brand. I do highly recommend this product to individuals participating in higher level education because of its immense upsides with few downsides.
The upsides to this particular product come primarily from the additional products that I purchased to pair with it. To begin, the Apple Pencil allows the consumer to be able to take the highest of quality digital notes within a variety of apps available in the App Store. Whether you're looking to annotate PDF document or edit a photo on Adobe Photoshop, the Apple Pencil gives you the personal touch. I primarily use the OneNote application to take notes because it syncs with my Microsoft 365 Account, which allows me to have my notes on all my devices. Carrying onto the Smart Keyboard, this addition allows one to type as if they were using a traditional keyboard on a tablet. When I first got my iPad I struggled typing with the touch screen keyboard, but as Ive transitioned to the Smart Keyboard I have been able to efficiently type emails, documents, as well as notes.
With all those upsides I have noticed some discouraging aspects to this product. One of the marketed features of this product was the ability to transfer your hand-written notes to typed documents. Ive downloaded many apps that claim that their app can fulfil this claim and Ive figured out that this claim is a bit of a stretch. Many of these apps aren't fully developed so the success rate of the transfer is very low. As I have taken notes on my new iPad for the past four weeks of school, Ive come to the conclusion that its not worth trying to convert my notes to text. Its proven to be a disappointment. If you're looking to enhance your educational experience, I recommend this product as you're okay with getting a little less than what is expected in the product.

The best iPad yet I upgraded from an iPad Air 2.

The screen on the iPad Pro is instantly recognizable once you've seen it side be side with an Air. It's automatic adjustments for color accuracy in various lighting conditions ('True Tone')makes for a much more comfortable viewing experience, and Apple's new 'night shift' only enhances that.

Having four speakers does significantly increase the volume range and makes it more possible for others to hear dialogue on the screen since the speakers are pointed outward in all directions. It also prevents accidentally covering a speaker from distorting an app's or song's audio too much.

The iPad Pro is also blazing fast. Every company makes a big deal out of so-called 'incremental' updates to their devices, but the A9X chip on the iPad Pro virtually eliminates app crashes (to the extent that Apple can prevent those from happening), has absolutely no lag. I've also experienced what may be a product of my perception but is nonetheless amazing: I get faster wireless internet speeds (I have gigabit fiber) on my iPad Pro than on my MacBook (12", 2016) or my 6s Plus often over half of a Gbps, versus the still very fast wi-if speeds that my MacBook and iPhone get, usually hanging around 30-50 Mbps (see speed test pictures).

As with every iPad I've had since the original iPad was released, Apple's seamless integration of hardware and software shines in their latest iteration of the most second most iconic piece of technology from the first decade of the 2000s (the first being the iPhone, of course). The keyboard on the pro is faster and more adaptive than ever; I'm writing this whole review on my Pro in portrait mode actually. Integrated iOS apps (the ones I use, at least, especially Safari) work flawlessly alongside Facebook, Twitter, Messages, and Mail. Touch ID is faster than it's ever been, with no lag, and enhances auto fill by unlocking stored passwords and credit cards in iCloud Keychain.

The only caveat I've had so far with my 9.7" iPad Pro is its inability to fit iPad Air 2 cases despite an identical design (new cam/mic layout and four speakers vs. two), and there are hardly any cases available for the iPad Pro, especially in its smaller size.

Apple's 'cases' for the iPad Pro are ridiculous. Like, totally ridiculous. Two of the photos below show how Apple's $50 silicone 'smart cover' is about 1/2 of a centimeter wider than the iPad itself, which makes carrying the device and holding it with the cover folded around the back of the device extremely uncomfortable. The quality is poor and the price is insane. Even worse, protecting the back is another $70 for a clunky silicone case that covers the back, making for an awkward two-piece cover that might have only cost pennies to make but is being sold for a total of $120.

I personally love the icarer leather cases. They're slim and fit well, and are of a much higher quality than Apple's cases despite the company's sometimes comically bad interpretations (icarer is based in Hong Kong and orders are fulfilled by Amazon).

I can't recommend the iPad Pro highly enough overall. Ultimately, the device is most fun to use without a case, and for $99, AppleCare+ will provide two replacements, even if the device is completely smashed, for $49 each. After that, though, you're out of luck.

I am, what most people consider, an Apple fan-boy. I have a MacBook Pro. An iMac. An iPhone. Two iPads. I haven't touched a Windows computer or Android phone in 5-10 years.

A week ago, I decided to get rid of my MacBook Pro and replace it with the new version coming out soon (I hope). So, I decided to try an experiment  my iPad Pro will be my 100% of the time computer. Just like Tim Cook claimed it is.

I write a lot. I am a prolific blogger with an extremely popular website. I write 1500 word posts with dozens of links and a few photos. I use a web-based application, so I'm not constrained by anything.

Let's see what I've observed. Good points:

1. Beautiful, especially in gold.
2. With a keyboard (I'm using the Logitech Create case/keyboard for this iPad), I can add content quickly and efficiently. It works like a laptop in that sense. In fact, I'm doing this review while typing at near my normal speed.
3. Screen is so refined, that I actually reduced font size to fit more content on the screen, and it's easily readable.
4. Sound, through four speakers, is amazing.
5. The Apple Pencil (dumb name there Apple, just saying) is much better than using your finger, mostly. There are some things that seem to be a tad buggy for my taste.
6. There is some multi-tasking abilities that allow me to move between apps quite quickly.
7. For all intents and purposes, if you started your computer life with just this iPad Pro, you'd probably be impressed. This "computer" is boatloads more powerful than my first laptop, a PowerBook, from the early 1990s. It's probably more powerful and speedy than anything I used up to 2010.

But there are really bad things about it that make it frustrating as a creating content device:

1. Cut and paste is horrible. Selecting a word is easy, but anything more than that takes time and skill, even with the Pencil.
2. Copying embedded links and pasting it elsewhere is worthless, in that it doesn't work at all. This is a basic requirement  if I find a sentence that has an embedded hyperlink, when I copy it to another document, the link should work. It doesn't do it. As a writer, this is very frustrating.
3. Since iOS lacks a file structure, it's difficult to save documents to a set location. However, iOS now has iCloud Drive, so it kind of works, though it feels unrefined.
4. The pencil sometimes doesn't do things like one's finger.
5. Image handling isn't the greatest thing in the world, but there are workarounds.

I'm going to experiment with using an iPad Pro for another week or so. I cannot agree with Apple's assessment that this is a computer. There are things that we take for granted on a computer, like trackpads and easy copy/paste, that are necessary to make this work better. If I move my hand from the keyboard, I really don't want to use the pencil, I want a refined trackpad, like Apple's own trackpads.

BUT, it's closer to being a laptop than the original iPad, by a long shot. We're not that far away, but Apple can be stubborn about making the changes that would make it a superior experience.

Now, if you want the iPad Pro for just a consumption device (music, videos, photos), this thing is a Five Star home run device. But if you want it for creating content, it falls short. One caveatif you're an illustrator or artist, then Pencil and iPad Pro is amazing. I just used it to do some doodles on Notes, and I was having a great time. And the Pencil works really well with the Amazon Kindle app, so highlighting and saving notes is incredible. I daresay the Kindle experience on the iPad Pro is superior to the Kindle device itself (though, it's close).

So, buy this device with your eyes wide open. If you want it to be a laptop, it can work, and it does it fairly well, despite some annoying quirks. Maybe over time, you (and I) can get used to it.

If you're an artist, you'll be impressed. It's just simply amazing.

If you're a consumer of content, the speakers and screen will be special.

Right now this is a four star device, for me. If ios 10 fixes some issues, I might move it to 5 star.

I bought this about a week ago in South Korea. I had owned an iPad before, but I sold it and have been using Android tablets. I have a Note 12.2 and a Nexus 7 2013. It seems Android tablets are lost their momentum. Companies do not make best Android tablets any more these days. Samsung released Tab S2 last year, but its CPU is not much faster than that of Note 12.2. And 12.2 is rather slow. So, I decided to buy an iPad Pro mainly for its top-notch performance.

The speed is fast as I expected. No more lagging and stutters while browsing the web. The speakers are good as a tablet: far better than that of Note 12.2, but of course not as good as decent PC speakers. The hardware is good, but the problems of iOS are bugging me.

So, here are the problems of iOS I have found.

1. Touch ID is not as good as I expected.
It seems as if Touch ID is an auxiliary substitution for your 6-digit PIN. You have to type in your PIN if you have restarted the iPad, even if you have enabled the Touch ID. Touch ID quite often fails to recognise my fingerprint if I tap slightly differently (the sensor is smaller than my thumb). If it fails 3 times, then you must enter your PIN. Also, if you enable Touch ID for unlocking, for some unknown reason, locking delay option gets disabled. That is, you have to provide your fingerprint, even if the iPad was just locked 3 seconds ago by screen time-out. This is really annoying. If you don't enable Touch ID, then you can set the locking delay to something like 30 minutes. Why Apple?
Also, if you enable Touch ID for App Store, you must provide your fingerprint for any and every download, even if they are free apps. For example if you download three free apps consecutively within 30 seconds, you must provide your fingerprint three times! What is the point? Why do I need to provide my fingerprint to download a free app?

2. Siri is useless when compared to Google Now.
The voice recognition does not work as well as Google Now. And unlike Google Now, there is no manual input box. I use Google Now all the time to search the web. With Siri, you have to speak, and Siri does not understand long sentences.

3. Notification bar is useless.
The drop-down notification bar is useless compared to that of Android. On Android, it shows on-going activities, useful actions, etc. On iOS there are just useless fixed "widgets". None of the widgets from 3rd party apps were useful. No widgets display on-going activities such as download progress. For example, on Note 12.2, I can turn off the VPN connection right from the notification bar. On iPad, I had to open the VPN app and turn it off (there is a button to turn off VPN in the settings app, but it did not work).
Also there is no shortcut to system settings in the notification bar or in the quick settings bar (slide up). I had to exit the app I was using and then find the system settings icon from the home screen and tap it to go to the settings.

4. Using multiple Apple ID's is very difficult.
On Android, all Google apps provide a unified, easy way to switch between multiple Google ID's. On iPad, you must sign out, and then type the ID and password of your other Apple ID. If your Apple ID is protected by two-step verification, you must do that each time, because there is no option for "don't ask again for this device".

5. No "web search" context menu for text selection.
This is really frustrating, because I search the web very often. Isn't it really easy to implement? On Android, if you select a word in any app, there is "web search" context menu. iOS has no such thing. I have to copy it and then open the web browser and paste it.

6. Dictionary pop-up is not customisable.
It seems the dictionaries are automatically set by your language settings. For example, I have set the system language to English UK, Oxford American English Dictionary is automatically added and cannot be removed. So, I have to scroll it each time to see the UK dictionary. And the dictionary font is really small and sometimes its background is black and the contrast is too low to be legible. Is it really that difficult to let us change the font or the colour?

I resisted using iPhones for the longest time because my Sony Ericssons had a better quality camera. When Sony moved over to Android, I took the plunge and bought an iPhone. Once I became proficient with iOS, I did not want to use another system. That's the primary reason I went with my first iPad Air. I use my iPad primarily as a toy. I don't need it for work and I prefer my desktop computer for any serious work. It's a worthy replacement for a laptop and much more convenient with better battery life. And then it happened... I was using my iPad to look up the wiring sequence on a dryer. I should have paid closer attention to the placement of my screwdriver. I was using a hefty Wiha screwdriver with the "full tang" butt. It landed squarely on top of my screen and promptly shattered it. I was distraught. It's not like I can't be without my iPad, but it felt like a pet in need. I had broken my companion. I was an unsuitable master! Although my iPad Air still worked, tiny shards of Gorilla Glass in my fingers were a constant reminder of my betrayal. I couldn't go on like this! Like any man in a desperate situation, I was not thinking clearly. Yes, I could have replaced my original iPad Air with a certified refurbished version for less than half the cost of this. I could have even upgraded to the Air II. That's when I saw the Pro. It wasn't that much more money. Would this redeem me in the eyes of the iPad gods? Before good sense could prevail I ordered my Pro 9.7" from Amazon (which promptly left the package unattended at my front door the next day with no signature required). So here I am a month later with my new toy. The screen is truly fabulous, the best I have seen on any tablet. It has bells and whistles I may never even discover. The sound is truly fantastic for a tablet. It does get fairly warm if you do any serious work on it, so I'm not sure how much AutoCAD work you will really accomplish. It does what I need and looks better than any other iPad while doing it. Did I really need the Pro? No, I suppose not. For my purposes I was fine with my original iPad Air. I do enjoy the multi-tasking feature and feel this was a worthwhile improvement. I did a fair amount of streaming on my old iPad which definitely looks and sounds better now on the Pro. When it all boils down, many users probably cannot justify the cost of the Pro over a lesser iPad, but does it matter? We don't buy what we need, we buy what we want. The Pro ticks just enough of the right boxes to justify its purchase (and it really isn't THAT much more than the standard iPad Air II. As for my original iPad Air, it was rescued with the addition of iPad Pro 9.7 inch Screen Protector It now lives in my garage for those times when I need to look up a part or need a write-up on changing an axle.

Apple just keeps on improving the iPad with each version (Obviously). Just don't make the mistake that this is a computer tablet. While it it functional for basic web browsing, email and games, it is nothing close to the Microsoft Surface series. All in all though, the build quality is excellent as you would expect from Apple and the screen is great. The kids love it. Personally for me I rather work on a full PC like the Microsoft Surface but my little kids love the iPad.
