So why did I return it? Did you know that you cannot use a mouse with an iPad? I'm not kidding. Imagine with me for a moment what it is like to try to move your cursor around in a Word document or an email. You put your finger on the touchscreen and press. Now understand that your finger itself covers up the exact spot you are trying to move your cursor to. Oops, I made the cursor move 2 spaces to the right of what I need. So I precariously move my finger over what I believe to be 2 spaces to the left and put it down on the screen. OK, getting better, it's still 1 space to the right but making progress. A third attempt and I now went too far to the left, but hey I'm bracketing the thing now. On my fourth try I nail it.

Now imagine doing that over and over, numerous times a day as you edit a Word document or an email. It's absolutely ridiculous. Why do they not allow a mouse? Especially on the very small 9.7 inch screen?

Yes this is a great reader, surfing the web is wonderful, and the apps are great. Fast, lightweight with a long battery, what's not to love? The lack of a mouse!

So I returned mine. Still searching for something like it, that allows use of a mouse.

I would like first to point out that I did not purchase the iPad Pro 9.7 from Amazon, I purchased it through AT&T, my cell carrier. I would also like to say that I am not a big fan Apple products, the iPad Pro is a rare occasion where I purchased an Apple product.

Besides the iPad Pro, I also have in my house: AT&T Trek HD, Samsung Galaxy Tab S2, Samsung Galaxy Tabe E, LG G Pad X. Obviously all these are not mine, but for various members of my family. But I have used them all. To be honest, they all work fine in their own right. The reason why I decided to buy the iPad Pro is because for the first time in many years, the iPad stood apart from all other tablets in performance.

With the A9X Processor and 2gb of RAM, the iPad Pro is fast. I have not experienced any lag in any of the tasks I've preformed and that includes watching movies and playing games like a "Heroes of the Galaxy".

The 2048 x 1536 resolution (264 ppi pixel density) on the iPad Pro 9.7 offers a crystal clear image and the best of I've seen on any tablet.

The 12 MP rear camera stands alone in the tablet market, there isn't another tablet that even comes close to the picture quality. Why might a person use this camera? I use the iPad Pro for work, my work requires me to take pictures on job sites and then type out a report. My iPad Pro serves this dual purpose. If you enjoy taking pictures, does it really matter what you take the pictures with? Nice pictures are what matter and the iPad Pro takes great pictures.

The fingerprint sensor works flawlessly.

I will say the "True Tone" display could use some improvement. Under certain nighttime conditions, it can give the display a slight yellow tinge. This is really the only real problem I have with the iPad Pro 9.7 and it is a very small problem.

The iPad Pro 9.7 is in my opinion the best tablet on the market when you consider size and power. It is expensive, so for some people other Apple tablets may be a better value. But if you have the money and you're looking for a high performance tablet, you won't regret owning the iPad Pro 9.7.

Apple makes you think their top of the line iPads have a GPS receiver by stating they support photo geotagging, but they fail to mention they don't include a few dollar GPS receiver so geotagging relies on WiFi instead.  This may be fine some places but on a recent trip the Caribbean our photos were all tagged as being hundreds of miles away in Florida.  In addition, we tried using the Navionics app on the iPad to act as a backup chartplotter for our boat but, since it doesn't have a few dollar GPS receiver, it wasn't up to the task.  We tried my friend's iPhone but the Navionics app is iPad-only so we were unable to use it.  We even tried finding an app that would let us tether his GPS to the iPad (something that's easily doable with Androids or Windows devices) so Navionics would work but, as usual, there is no way to do this with Apple devices :/  It's possible the cellular-enabled iPads have GPS, though Apple's product page doesn't say it so I doubt it.  Such a shame that Apple wouldn't include this on ALL iPads...

On top of everything, I ran across bugs and UI glitches while using the iPad, and the app selection has totally changed since I last owned an iPhone back in 2006!  It used to be that Apple had more apps and they were better quality than Android.  Now the opposite is true - Androids have so many more apps and can do SO much more there's no comparison.  As for app quality, they're about the same - some apps crash on Androids and some crashed on my iPad, but that's on the app developers not Apple or Google.

Needless to say, my iPad trial was a huge disappointment so back to Amazon it goes, I'll stick with my Androids and Windows devices which cost a lot less and can do SO MUCH more.  I was not expecting this, I was expecting to be blown away after not owning an Apple product for 10 years, I figured they would be light years ahead of the competition.  Heck, I even bought accessories for the iPad that can't be returned because I expected to keep it!  But I'd rather waste a few bucks on a case and charging cable than $700 on a paperweight :D

I've used Apple products for about 11 years now since I got an iPod.  I've had mostly positive experiences with Apple products with a few minor exceptions and although I have owned many different Apple devices I would not consider myself a "fanboy."

This is my 5th iPad and I have to say, I'm very happy having used it over the past month.  I use my tablet mainly for browsing the internet, checking and writing emails, shopping on Amazon, watching Youtube, watching movies, and misc other things.  I could have very well went with a Surface or an Android Tablet of similar specs for less money but I've been satisfied with my iPads and have always been pleased with the functionality and the battery life.

Unless you're looking for a larger screen, this is without a doubt the best iPad and in general a solid tablet.  One of the main reasons I bought this was because I also like sketching on my tablets and up until now, the experience has always been just so-so at best for Apple. I actually considered the iPad Pro but the large screen was just too much for me and I wanted something more portable.  When I saw this iPad Pro release I knew it would be something to consider.  I have been using the iPad Mini for the past few generations and I really liked the size but I didn't mind stepping up in size if that meant a big increase in capabilities.

This iPad is the fastest it has ever been, the screen looks fantastic, the stereo speakers are great, the Apple Pencil is one of the best styli I've ever used, and I really like the new smart connector for the keyboards.  The new processor handles everything very well and multitasking on it with this iPad works better than ever.  The multitasking was one of my newer favorite features on the iPad but it really hasn't been implemented as well as I would have liked and could be a little slow or janky on my other iPad Mini 4.  With this iPad it is quick and simple and although the software for multitasking could be improved a bit, the feature works very well.

The speakers have turned out to be another new favorite feature.  They sound good, the stereo sound improves watching movies exponentially, and they can get loud without much distortion.  Watching movies and videos is a far better experience with the good looking screen and  the speakers.

There are a lot of great features with this iPad that I could go into but won't for the sake of keeping this slightly shorter, however another thing to point out is how much better the camera is.  I believe it matches the iPhone 6s Plus camera which is probably one of the better cameras on a tablet so far.  I don't use the camera much honestly but it is a nice addition.  Also, I have not bought or used the smart keyboard but will eventually make use of the smart connector.

Now it is hard to go into the capabilities with the Apple Pencil because it is not included with the iPad and is also part of the reason this iPad gets 4 stars instead of 5 for my review.  The Apple Pencil is just awesome.  I may not have had a lot of experiences with different high end styli but using the Apple Pencil is unlike any experience I have ever had with a stylus and a touch screen.  It feels good going against the glass and the pressure sensitivity and using the Pencil at angles feels perfect and intuitive.  It really comes close to the feeling of using a pen or pencil on paper and if I was still in college I would very likely use it to take notes in class.

While the functionality of the Apple Pencil along with the capabilities of this iPad to use it are amazing, the Pencil doesn't come with the iPad and there is not place to store it easily on the device.  While the storage issue isn't a big deal, one of this iPads main features over the iPad Airs that came before is using the Pencil.  If you didn't plan on using the Apple Pencil then I might just suggest you spend far less money and get the last iPad Air instead.  Not only is the Pencil not included but it cost $100 which isn't all that affordable although what Apple product really is.
Another issue I have is that this is the newest Apple device and one of the best new features with the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus is the 3D Touch which this iPad does not have.  While the 3D touch may seem a bit of a gimmick, it is another great input option for touch screens that would have made for a great addition on this new iPad.  I personally think it should have made it into the feature set and along with not including a Pencil, this is why the iPad Pro 9.7 gets 4 stars from me.

Considering the price and especially the price including the Apple Pencil, it can be hard to recommend this new iPad Pro 9.7.  With the 128GB version that I got along with the Apple Pencil, the total comes to around $850 without even buying a case or a keyboard.  When you're spending that much money you could definitely look into some of the Surface tablets that include the stylus and a keyboard or if you're not even interested in a stylus and keyboard, you could spend a lot less getting a Samsung tablet.  However, if you're like me and enjoy your Apple products, are maybe a little invested in iTunes, and aren't as bothered by paying a premium then I can easily recommend this iPad.  It is fast, the battery lasts for around 10 hours, the Apple Pencil is great, and it just works well.  If you're in the market for a new iPad, you really can't go wrong getting this one.

I'll update my review should I find any glaring issues and I can answer any questions.

Great new iPad... This is my second iPad.  Only draw back is that you need to have access to the internet to use it.

I've owned almost all the iPad models in the past, and this is the snappiest and fastest device yet. Launching apps and camera, unlocking the device using the fingerprint, volume controls,  orientation changing, Bluetooth, ambient light sensor, and etc, just every function and feature on this device works the way I expected and executes every command without any issue. I've been using this device for several months now, and I haven't found one single issue.
The screen is the most beautiful part. I've noticed the gab between the surface glass, and the LCD panel underneath is almost non existent. When I read a book on the iPad, it feels as if the texts are right on the surface (just like the texts are printed on a paper). I enjoy more and more reading on this device these days than on a Kindle.
Ambient light sensor also works fantastically. It senses the amount of light around the space I'm in very accurately and controls the brightness automatically and accordingly so my eyes don't get strained easily. True Tone is another nice feature on this model. At first I wasn't comfortable with the automatic color temperature shift on the screen, but soon, I felt ease on my eyes with this feature on compared to my iPhone screen without the True Tone feature.
I bought the LTE version because only this model in tablet is compatible with t-mobile's Extended Range LTE (band 12). With my T-mobile data plan on this iPad, I get better connectivity than on my phone, and it's been reliable on the road when I travel. Especially with all the perks (BingeOn, Music Freedom) from T-mobile plan, this iPad couldn't be more useful on the road or outside.

Overall, this is my go-to device that is light, portable, fast, and beautiful. Of course it doesn't replace my work laptop that runs photo/video editing applications, but for almost everything else, this device does it in such an efficient way. Battery lasts long enough (pretty much all day), and the new 4 speakers are nice (finally, stereo sound!) I debated between this 9.7" and 12.9" before I made the purchase, and I don't regret choosing this one. Bigger screen size can benefit the user when consuming medias, but it is little too big to carry around.
One thing I am not happy with is the 'swapped magnet polarity' for Smart Cover. My old iPad Air covers are not compatible with this new pro version anymore. Other than that, I am quite satisfied with this newest version, and I hope it stays that way for the next 4-5 years.

This new iPad Pro 9.7" model is very similar to my already excellent iPad Air 2, but the two speakers on that model do not sound good at high volume. Rather irritating to the ears. This new "Pro" model has four speakers (not two), and the sound is quite a bit better, on par with my old iPad 3rd Generation, which is mono. Volume wise, the old 3rd Generation is still a bit louder and clearer than the new "Pro," but because it has one speaker, it is not quite as easy to hear in another room. It may be the laws of sound acoustics in physics.

Performance is a little better on the "Pro," but not by a long shot. It is as good for browsing the Internet, and opening many documents as on the iPad Air 2. However, it charges the battery slowly on USB 2.0. Every single iPad that Apple has made, regardless of its connector, will charge faster on a USB 3.0 computer. Yes, even charging in the wall is slow as if it were USB 2.0. The connector that goes into the wall is a USB 2.0, which very few people actually know. I have done some experimentation to prove this. If you have a MacBook Pro, Mac Pro (2013 model), or PC with USB 3.0, you will have a faster charging cycle. Still, the iPad 3rd Generation has the best battery life, because it is thicker with a larger mA (milliAmp count) rating.

Camera. OK, it is better than the iPad Air 2 (the 3rd Generation iPad--poor-fair in good light). Comparing the photos to my iPhone 6s Plus, they aren't on par. Nice to have the LED flash--a first for an iPad, and works fine for a flashlight. Caused blurry photos, iPhone doesn't do that most often. Rolling shutter is very noticeable, just slightly more evident than on the iPhone 6s Plus. Hunts a good bit in low-light because it doesn't have image stabilization and continuous autofocus found in the iPhone 6s Plus. Even taking a photo during video does not exist. I realize that the iPhone is better suited for camera work, and probably always will be. However, even though it can record 4K video and 12 MP stills, it does not quite match the iPhone 6s Plus. Many reviewers have stated it takes great photos and videos, and has the camera from the iPhone 6s Plus, but I don't see that. What is good about using the camera on an iPad is that you can really see what you are capturing because of the big display. Even the new Microsoft Surface Pro's front camera is on par with the iPhone 6 (not the 6s models). I tested it out at a local retailer, pretty amazing.

I would not recommend any "Pro" iPad over the Air 2 model if you already have one, unless you can't stand the grating sound through the flat speakers, and want to take photos with a flash. It is more practical to use the iPad as a very portable computer, nothing else for serious use. Aim for the largest capacity because it makes you look cool, and that you are the least likely to run out of space.

Four stars for being just a minor upgrade over the Air 2, but as always, I really like Apple products, and they are of great quality. No complaints about Apple here, they're wonderful, products are top notch, all good there... The issue is Amazon.

After my iPad was hit by a car, I figured it was time to get another one. So, placing the order on June 16, the site estimated that the product would be to me by June 23 or 24. Come June 19 I was curious, as the device had not yet shipped. The telephone support agent was helpful and said that the device should arrive as scheduled no later than June 23. Pleased, I went about my business. June 23 came, and still the package had not shipped. I called again. This support agent was friendly and helpful and upgraded the item to priority next day shipping. So, I was again quite pleased. Come June 28 I got a confirmation that the item would arrive the next day (June 29). Fine with that, I again went about my business. The next day I got an email stating that the order would be delayed yet another day, now arriving on the 30th of June and still the item has not shipped. Peeved, I called the support line a third time and spoke with two clearly unseasoned support agents (one who said he was a 'supervisor in-charge'). They were snippy and impatient speaking through their teeth the entire time as I asked for some form of compensation for the significant delays. (I've never asked for something like this, ever!)

As a Prime member I had read the contract and knew that a one-month extension to my membership would be afforded as a given, but seeing as two weeks had elapsed, I felt justified in asking for a bit more. The first agent offered a mere 10 dollars in store credit on a 750+ dollar item, the second offered up to 30 dollars and a month of additional time on my membership and ended the call in a huff (without my consultation) one might consider that being 'hung up on'. Unsatisfied, I am still not in receipt of the iPad and am writing this review since the Amazon telephone support agents don't seem to like speaking with me (Now, I was respectful and kept a measured tone the entire time despite the less than friendly reception I got on the other side of that call)... Anyway, I'll provide an update if/when this device arrives.

QUICK SIDE NOTE TO THOSE WHO ALREADY OWN THE 12.9 VERSION: Apple let me return the 12.9 (6 months after I bought it!) for the 9.7. If you already own the larger one and wish you had the smaller one, go to your local Apple store and ask to return it. They were super helpful/understanding with me.

I owned the 12.9 version and absolutely loved it. I own a Macbook Pro, Mac mini, Apple TV, Apple Watch, iPad Air, plus an iPhone, and the iPad Pro was BY FAR my favorite device out of all of them. In the end, I found the 9.7 version to be slightly more portable and therefore better suited to my needs. However, let me be clear: I highly recommend either product. The 12.9 and 9.7 are both fantastic. It really comes down to personal preference on screen size.

I wanted to write a review for people who were debating the cost of this tablet vs. less expensive alternatives. The saying, "you get what you pay for" is entirely accurate for the tablet market. The entry level price for the iPad Pro 9.7 is $698 ($599 for the iPad Pro, $99 for the Apple Pencil, which is absolute MUST HAVE for this device.) This device WILL NOT outright replace a laptop (for most people). So yes, this is an expensive tablet. Now I am not someone who thinks Apple is the only company capable of having good ideas or great products. If you're on a budget, there are less expensive options out there (Id' recommend the Nexus 7 or Asus Zenpad S8, I own both) But at $698, the iPad Pro 9.7 OUT PREFORMS it's cost. Sure, you can pay $300 for a Samsung tablet, but it will underwhelm you in comparison, as will the iPad Air 2.

The iPad Pro is hands down the fastest tablet available (This isn't debatable, numbers don't lie). It feels as fast if not faster than any computer or laptop I've ever used. But the speed is not what you'll fall in love with.

In my opinion, the Apple Pencil is what sets this tablet apart from any other tablet. YOU DO NOT NEED TO BE AN ARTIST TO HAVE A USE FOR THE APPLE PENCIL! I own my own business. I constantly have to annotate PDF files, sign documents, jot notes down. Being able to preform these tasks digitally is not only MUCH more convenient, it's fun! You can mark up things and email them back instantly. For me this is invaluable. You can take a picture (with THE BEST camera on a tablet, again, not debatable) throw it in Notes and use the Apple Pencil to handwrite a few notes about it, and send it away. For this specific task, it is better to have an iPad Pro than a laptop.

In addition, the speakers are amazing. Seriously, 11 out of 10 for a mobile device. I cannot understate this. They sound great and they are loud enough to entertain a small party. My bluetooth speaker has been sitting on the shelf since I bought the iPad Pro. Recently took a vacation to Florida and brought the iPad Pro to the pool. To own an ultra portable device that you can store all of your music on and play it on its internal speakers without having to pair it to some other battery driven device is awesome to me! Around the house, I listen to podcasts on it all of the time. I can leave the room and still hear it in the kitchen. I absolutely love the speakers and simply will not purchase another tablet unless they can match these speakers. I cannot go without them now.

The iPad Pro has a number of other amazing features that I'm sure the other reviews will highlight. I will end my review with this: This is undoubtedly the best tablet available. As with almost anything, if you want the best, it's going to cost you more. My advice to anyone willing to spend around $350 for a tablet OR laptop, spend the extra money to purchase an iPad Pro instead. It will run circles around any tablet or laptop in that price range, and from my experience, it will become the favorite electronic device that you've ever bought.

My last review of a new iPad began with a confession which I repeat-I am an iPad addict. My illness has not abated. I am no closer to a cure than I was in October, 2014 when I got my hands on an iPad Air 2. At best I control my obsession.

I have owned every generation of the iPad (all WiFi plus cellular) since it was introduced in 2010. It has become an indispensable tool in my litigation practice. Other lawyers, lugging large boxes of files for short hearings are often amazed as my iPad swiftly retrieves documents  I purposely avoided the 12 in iPad Pro as I found it too large for my purposes. Apple 9.7 inch iPad Pro was worth the wait.

Although cellular capacity, may not be a necessity for all, I frequently find myself in courtrooms and law offices which do not have accessible WiFi. Cellar lets me surf, upload files and documents from my file server and use Facebook when I am waiting for something to begin.

There are some significant improvements over my iPad Air 2. The first is speed  The A9X chip is extremely fast. Although the previous A8X chip in the Air 2 was faster than its predecessor, the difference is noticeable.

Cameras are greatly upgraded. The front camera as a resolution of 12 MP whIle the back camera, mostly used for selfies and Skyping and FaceTime, weighs in with 5 MP. HOwever it is the video that will most impress. Video can be shot in 4K which will lead to cinema quality movies of home birthday parties being shown to grandparents everywhere.

The upgraded camera undoubtedly is why Apple has discontinued the 64 GB model. The iPad Pro is only available in 32, 128, 256 GB models. The smallest may well have storage problems but it too is a doubling of the former 16 GB unit. If you are going to opt for the 32 GB iPad, have a backup storage plan in place. Otherwise your iPad will fill quickly. On the other hand, 256 GB seems like overkill.

One of the most interesting improvements is in the display. Reading books on iPad using the Kindle app has largely been an indoor-only enterprise. The ability to read in bright light has bee'n best handled on a Kindle e-book reader. That singular advantage has disappeared. iPad adjusts for lighting conditions making reading comfortable inside or out.

One of the heavily promoted accessories is the Apple Pencil. It is technogically advanced. I tried it. It is perfect for drawing. That is not one of my strengths. I did watch one prospect creating a spectular sketch and then carefully coloring it.

For those who wish to replace a laptop with an iPad Pro, this model like its bigger bother had snap on keyboard. Although I use my iPad extensively in my law practice, I am not yet ready to ditch my MacBook Pro. Perhaps that day will come for me, but it's not here yet.

One accessory I did buy was a smart cover. In spite of its close resemblance to the iPad Air 2, the smart covers are not interchangeable. This suggests that those who prefer cases will find similar incompatibility.

Finally!, one of the biggest mistakes iPad neophytes make is failing to buy AppleCare Plus.

This is a tricky device to rate and review, mainly due to Apple's categorizing it as a Pro device.  As such, it's a bit underwhelming in a few ways.  As an "iPad Air 3", however, it's outstanding right out of the box.

True Tone Display, A9X chip,  Pencil support, improved cameras (front and back), four auto-adjusting stereo speakers - all of those are remarkable... and likely upgrades many would have expected from Apple had they simply announced an iPad Air 3.  Instead, they repackage their 9.7" offering as a smaller version of the iPad Pro, and touted it during the Keynote (and on their site) as "...the ultimate upgrade for ANY iPad owner"... and priced it as such.  It's here that I have a bit of a problem.

I may be a bit unique here, in that I upgraded from the still-fast iPad Air 2 and not a much older model.  I also have a 12.9" iPad Pro, and I can accurately state that the speed/performance boost does not warrant the "Pro" moniker for the smaller iPad.  In day-to-day usage, I'm seeing maybe a second or so speed increases.  Sometimes more, sometimes less.  It's blazing fast, but so was the Air 2.  It even shares the same 2GB of RAM that the iPad Air 2 and iPad mini 4 have, half of what the larger Pro contains.  Apple's mastery of software optimization aside, this is troubling, especially when you consider that just last year the key feature of "iPad multitasking" was reserved for "Apple's most powerful tablet" - i.e. the iPad Air 2, which had the most RAM of any iOS device at the time.  With iOS 10 on the horizon, potential new features that may be hardware-intensive might only be available for the 12.9" Pro, which would be a hard pill to swallow for owners of Apple's NEWEST "Pro" device.  If that turns out to not be the case, then it's irritating for another reason: the "lowly" iPad Air 2 and iPad mini 4 can perform those same tasks - all for HUNDREDS of dollars less.  RAM requires battery, heat dissipation, etc. - I get that.  Perhaps just two speakers (top and bottom in portrait view, which would still have been an improvement over the Air 2's one loud speaker) instead of four would have been a better move. That would allow for more battery space, and perhaps a happy medium of 3GB of RAM.

The use of the "Pro" moniker here (iOS limitations themselves aside) stems entirely from the optional accessories - the  Pencil and Smart Keyboard.  With the larger Pro, even without the Pencil (which you REALLY DO want/need) or the Keyboard, it still lives up to its Pro name more accurately, if only by sheer screen real estate. This makes multitasking rather natural and infinitely more pleasant.  In landscape, it's essentially two 9.7" iPad devices in portrait mode, side by side.

Apple also chose to not include their newer 2nd Gen Touch ID sensor, showcased in the newest iPhones, as well as opting for a USB 2 Lightning port (12.9" iPad Pro has the much faster USB 3 port).  It's little things like this that make you scratch your head and go "Why, Apple?? Were you afraid we'd think it was TOO perfect?"  Apple does this quite a bit, actually... it's infuriating.

It may sound like I don't like this 9.7" version, which couldn't be further from the truth.  Apple has produced a powerhouse of a tablet in a familiar form factor with an absolutely beautiful screen (superior to the larger Pro's offering in several critical ways), much improved sound (not as full as the 12.9", but worlds better than any previous iPad), and drastically improved cameras.  The latter may be laughed at or under-appreciated, but there are times when taking pictures with an iPad is extremely convenient: you're somewhere reading or doing something in an app, and a photo op presents itself.  Instead of closing or putting down your iPad and locating/fumbling with your iPhone (particularly the 6s/6s Plus and their ridiculously-fast Touch ID that renders the lockscreen camera nearly inaccessible), you now have access to the same 12MP/4k iSight camera on your iPad.  Scanning documents is another useful strength here.  A TrueTone flash... why not?  The improved 5MP front-facing FaceTime camera is a godsend; I'm not a selfie guy, but my wife and I FaceTime often, particularly when we're deployed.  Clearer video is always a good thing.  At 6.1mm thin - thinner than the iPhone - it obviously sports the much-complained-about protruding camera lens on the back.  I don't have a problem with it, personally, and it doesn't cause any wobbling if you're typing on a flat surface (lens cover is sapphire, so no need to worry about scratching).  Then again, I don't mind the bump on the iPhone either, so if you're one that hates that, it's something to consider.  Most cases will alleviate this "problem".

Aside from the camera bump and speaker grilles, the only other external difference you'll be able to spot lies on the side: the Smart Connector, which allows for direct connectivity of certain accessories.  Apple's own Smart Keyboard (9.7") is awesome, and though a bit more cramped than the larger version, it's still an outstanding typing experience with snap-n-play simplicity and good looks.

This iPad also supports the  Pencil, which is wonderful.  For some reason, the latency seems the tiniest smidge behind that of the larger iPad Pro, but it's still far and away the best stylus/writing input I've ever used (and I've used most).

Pricing... look, I'm usually the first to defend Apple and their pricing.  Not only as a reflection of their quality - they do produce some of the best products - but the fact that people KNOW Apple, and they KNOW about Apple's prices.  No need to go complaining about it... pay to play, or don't.  Having said that, for what you're getting with this tablet out of the box, the $100 markup from the previous 9.7" model (and all of the ones prior) is simply unjustified.  It is a BEAST of an iPad Air, but you don't get really any "Pro" unless you spend another $250 on the Pencil and Keyboard (and that's not even getting into the ridiculous price markup they did with the covers/cases). Although I feel the larger Pro offers a bit more "Pro" by virtue of its screen for productivity multitasking and creative professionals, it too is overpriced - almost ridiculously so, and likely in such a way to provide a justified cushion for this 9.7" version's pricing.

PROS:
TrueTone Display, with wide color gamut and extra-low reflectivity coating
Bright Screen (considerably brighter than the 12.9" version)
Familiar size
Intelligent stereo speakers x4
Improved iSight (12MP) and FaceTime (5MP) cameras, w/TrueTone and Retina Flash
A9X chip offers outstanding power
 Pencil support
Awesome, compact Smart Keyboard support
Sub-1lb weight
256GB storage option
Traditional "very good" iPad battery life (10+ hours of continuous video)

CONS:
Screen size doesn't lend itself to "Pro" moniker
Price - you're effectively paying more for the ability to use expensive accessories (sold separately)
2GB RAM, same as iPad Air 2 and iPad mini 4 (12.9" iPad Pro has 4GB)
A9X chip clocked lower than the 12.9" version, affecting processing and graphics power
First-gen Touch ID
USB 2 lightning port (USB 3 for 12.9" version, significantly faster charging option available)

As a "Pro" device, it's a bit short on features, and you need to spend quite a bit more to squeeze out the few features that are there.  PC (personal computer) replacement?  For MILLIONS of people... yes, but then, so were previous iPads.  Scoff if you must, but it's the truth.  As an all-around iPad, it's by far the best they've ever made.  The sticky part is that most, if not all, of the the additions are what you'd expect from a typical Apple upgrade, and those have historically been kept at a particular price - starting at $499.  If Apple had managed to keep the pricing the same, or offer compelling, must-have, on-device features, it would be a no-brainer.  Shame... it really is the best tablet available, and the best iPad ever.  The pricing and occasional "...but it's already available on the older version!!" feature omission knocks down (a bit) what would be an easy perfect score, 5-star product.

Overall 4.5/5
Good performance
